tutorial.title: Typewriter Portfolio
tutorial.descriptionContent: Embrace the charm of yesteryears with a modern twist! In this project, we're crafting a personal portfolio page styled like a classic typewriter. Your achievements, experiences, and skills are 'typed out' on screen, presenting your journey in a captivating and nostalgic manner.

executableContent.instructions:
Welcome to the **Typewriter Portfolio** project, where we'll build a classy portfolio. We'll design a portfolio page styled like a classic typewriter.

1. Let's first create the HTML file. Start off by setting the doctype and creating the basic layout with the `html` and `body` tags.
2. Add the `head` section and include the `title` tag with the title you like. In addition, link your HTML file to the CSS file named style.css.

Let's lay out the structure of the portfolio.

1. Create `header` within the `<body>` tag. Inside the `header`, add a `h1` heading with text that you like to display and an empty `nav` element.

files.name: index.html
files.solvedContent: Welcome to Tara's Portfolio

executableContent.instructions:
The `nav` element is intended to contain major navigation blocks. In our case, it will hold links to different portfolio sections.

1. Inside the `nav` element, add 3 `a` tags, each one linking to a particular section, `"About Me"`, `"Skills"`, and `"Projects"`. For this project, we'll work with the three aforementioned sections. You can later change them as you wish. 
2. Each link should contain the respective `href` attribute pointing to the id of the section. For now, use placeholders, like `#about`, `#skills`, or `#projects`, for the link targets.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Welcome to Tara's Portfolio
files.solvedContent:
Welcome to Tara's Portfolio

About Me Skills Projects

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we've added the links to the `nav` element, let's create respective sections in HTML, starting with `About Me`.

1. Create a `section` element and set its `id` to `"about"`.
2. Inside the section, add an `h2` heading with the section name - like `About Me` - and a `p` element with some text.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Welcome to Tara's Portfolio

About Me Skills Projects
files.solvedContent:
Welcome to Tara's Portfolio

About Me Skills Projects

About Me

My name is Tara. I'm an aspiring developer. Besides spending time coding, I love hiking through the woods with my dog, Brutus.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add a section for your skills. Each skill should be represented by a progress bar showing the progress of learning that skill. 

1. Create a section with the ID `"skills"`.
2. Inside the section, include an `h2` heading and at least three `div` elements with `class` set to `"skill-item"`.
3. Inside each `div` element, add a `progress` element with a unique ID and a `value` attribute that represents your skill progress.
4. Above each `progress` element, add a `label` element for each skill with the `for` attribute set to the ID of the `progress` element. Set the content of each `label` element to the name of the skill (e.g., `HTML`).

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Welcome to Tara's Portfolio

About Me Skills Projects

About Me

My name is Tara. I'm an aspiring developer. Besides spending time coding, I love hiking through the woods with my dog, Brutus.

executableContent.instructions:
We've already created several projects throughout your learning journey — it's time to share them.

1. Create a section with the ID `"projects"`.
2. Inside the section, add an `h2` heading and a `div` element with `class` set to `"project-list"`.
3. To the project list, add a project using a `detail` element that includes a `summary` element and a more detailed project description.

hints.title: How to use the `detail` and `summary` tags?
hints.content:
This is an example of how your code could look: ```HTML
Caesar Cipher

A small project I built for a friend to help exchange secret messages.

→ Link to project
```

executableContent.instructions:
Every portfolio needs a profile picture.

1. Add an `img` tag with the `src` set. It fits well below the `h2` element of your first section.
2. Set the `class` to `"profile"`.
3. Also, add a meaningful `alt` attribute.

Feel free to add your own image, but if you want a placeholder for now, go with the following image for now:

```HTML
https://mimo.app/i/tara.png
```

executableContent.instructions:
Next, we'll add some basic initial styles to the portfolio page.

1. Import the font `Courier Prime` from Google Fonts using the `@import` rule in the CSS file. 
2. Create a rule for the `body` element, setting `font-family` to `"Courier Prime", monospace`, `margin` and `padding` to `0px`, `background-color` to `#f4f4f4`, and `color` to `black`.

This is the snippet you need to import the `Courier Prime` font:

```CSS
@import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Courier+Prime&display=swap');
```

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Let's style the `header`.

1. Create a rule to target all `header` elements.
2. Center align the text and add `padding` to the `header`.
3. Also, add a dashed border to the bottom of the `header`.

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Now, style the navigation links.

1. Create rules for the `a` element and for `a:hover`.
2. Remove the underline from the links and set the color to black.
3. Also, add some `margin` to each link.
4. For the hover effect, underline the link when the mouse hovers, using `text-decoration`.

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add some style to the profile picture.

1. Create a rule to target all images with the class `"profile"` by coding `img.profile`.
2. Give it a width and height of 150px.
3. Make it round by setting `border-radius` to `50%`.
4. Set a border you like.
5. Set the `display` to `block` and margin to `auto` to center the image.

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
There's only one thing left to style: the projects section.

1. Create a rule to target the `details` elements.
2. Set `display` to `flex`.
3. Add a dashed border to `details`.
4. Provide `padding` and `margin` inside the details element.
5. Create a rule for `details:hover`.
6. Change the border of details to solid when hovered over.
